properties.entry: Gateway is currently in failsafe mode.
Gateway''s total connected node count {0} is higher than recommended.
Gateway''s total connected node count {0} has reached the maximum limit.
An outage notification has been received.
Gateway''s total ready node count ({0}) is lower than the warning threshold ({1}).
Gateway security alarm, SSH service enabled.

The Infrastructure Warnings widget periodically evaluates devices associated with the communications network such as RF gateways, RF relays, CCUs or repeaters. Results of the evaluations will produce informational or warning messages about specific conditions that may require investigation. A summary of the devices with and without warnings will be displayed in the top left corner of the page, along with an option to download all infrastructure warnings.
  • Devices without warnings (Green) - Number of devices without any of the below mentioned warning types.
  • Devices with warnings (Orange) - Number of devices with warnings.
In the top right corner, select any device types to filter the list and click on the Filter button. A table will display with the device, type, warning message and warning time. Click on the filtered cog dropdown to perform collection actions, download or map the filtered results.

The following is a list of the types of warnings that are being evaluated:
  • Gateway connection status – Warning condition produced if a gateway has not communicated with the Yukon software in a specified period of time. It may indicate a bulk communications issue with that particular gateway.
  • Duplicate gateway color found - Warning condition produced when two gateways on the RF network have the same color setting. The condition indicates a misconfigured gateway.
  • Gateway is in failsafe mode – Warning condition produced when a gateway enters failsafe mode. A gateway enters this mode when it is unable to execute the gateway application code or the application is restarted in quick succession. This can be caused by a series of outages, or by a problem with the gateway hardware or software. Note that gateways in failsafe mode will only communication with Yukon software and will not gather data from the RF nodes. After 24 hours in failsafe mode, the gateway will automatically attempt to boot back into normal mode.
  • Gateway total connected nodes – Condition produced when a gateway reaches a specified total node count that could affect the network’s ability to fully absorb a neighboring gateway’s nodes should it be needed. A low-severity warning is issued for this condition. A high-severity warning is issued when a gateway reaches the maximum total node count supported by the device.
  • Gateway data streaming capacity – Condition produced when a gateway is approaching or has surpassed the available bandwidth provided for the data streaming functionality. A low-severity warning is issued when a gateway reaches the defined data streaming capacity limits. This condition is primarily informational since a fully load gateway should not impact the performance of the network. A high-severity warning is issued when a gateway has significantly exceeded the defined data streaming capacity and intervention may be needed to reduce any impacts on network performance due to this condition.
  • Gateway ready node count - Condition produced when a gateway drops below the expected minimum ready node count.
  • Relay outage event – Warning condition produced when a ‘Last Gasp’ outage notification is received from a relay. This condition will automatically clear when the relay’s restoration notification is received.
  • PLC CCU communication status – Warning condition produced when ten consecutive messages targeting the specified CCU fail to be delivered. This may indicate a bulk communication problem between the Yukon software and the device.
  • PLC Repeater communication status - Warning condition produced when ten consecutive messages targeting the specified Repeater fail to be delivered. This indicates a communication problem between the Yukon software and the device.
